Dear Ms. Mahoney:
Attached is the Interim Report for the above referenced facility completed on 01/28/2019.
Due to the violations of applicable licensing rules, sections of the contract and
Implementation Sustainability and Exit Plan (ISEP) requirements, a written corrective
action plan is required. It should be noted that violations of any licensing rules are also
violations of the ISEP and your contract. The corrective action plan is due 15 days from
the date of this letter and must include the following:
 How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
 Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
licensing statute and rule or section of the contract or ISEP citation.
 An explanation why previous corrective action plans have not
obtained and maintained compliance for rules found in repeat
noncompliance.

 Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
 How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
 The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action may result.

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
1.) The facility is in compliance with all applicable licensing statutes and rules except
for the following:
MCL 722.120 Investigation, inspection, and examination of conditions,
books, records, and reports; access by department, bureau
of fire services, or local authorities; records; report; forms;
confidentiality; disclosure of information; availability of
confidential records; child information cards to be provided
to department; failure of licensee to cooperate with
investigation, inspection, or examination.
(3) A licensee shall keep the records the department prescribes
regarding each child in its control and care and shall report to
the department, when requested, the facts the department
requires with reference to the children upon forms furnished by
the department. Except as otherwise provided in this subsection
and subsection (4), records regarding children and facts
compiled about children and their parents and relatives are
confidential and disclosure of this information shall be properly
safeguarded by the child care organization, the department, and
any other entity in possession of the information.
One of seven special evaluations reviewed mentioned a
children protective service’s investigation/ report, disclosed
information about the parent and children, and listed the
children’ service’s report number.
Repeat Violation, Renewal 2017, Interim 2016, Renewal
2015.
R400.12212 Personnel records.
(3) The personnel record shall contain both of the following:
(a) A written evaluation of a staff member's performance
within a probationary period or not later than 6 months after the
staff member assumes his or her current responsibilities. After
the initial evaluation, a written evaluation shall be conducted
each year.
Fifteen of seventy-four employee records reviewed did not show
compliance:
 Twelve of sixty-five new employee records reviewed
showed the employee’s probationary or six-month
evaluation was completed late, with lateness ranging
from ten day to five months.
4

 Two of nine employee records reviewed where the
employee was employed over one year showed the
annual evaluation was eleven and fourteen days late
respectively. A third record did not document the
evaluation date and it could not be discerned if the
evaluation was timely.
Repeat Violation, Interim 2016.
R 400.12306 Application request.
(3) An agency shall document that a person who has met the

documentation that a copy of the updated act was provided the
foster parent.
R400.12312 Foster parent training.
(4) At least 1 adult member of the household shall have training
in and maintain a current certification in first aid from the
American Heart Association or the American Red Cross or other
institution approved by the department.
Of seven open foster home records reviewed, three did not

 One did not show documentation of first aid training for

 Two others showed the foster parent’s first aid had
expired 2/12/17 and 3/20/17 respectively.

(8) An agency shall complete a reevaluation and shall make a
licensing recommendation to the department at least 15

(3) An agency shall complete a special evaluation within 45
calendar days after receipt of the information. If additional time
is required, then the agency shall inform the foster parent, in

the extension. The total time for the completion of the

approval from the chief administrator or his or her designee.
In one of seven special evaluations reviewed the evaluation
exceeded 90 calendar days and approval from the chief

Repeat Violation, Interim 2016.

(5) Within 15 days of the conclusion of the evaluation, an

(b) Identification of the information source, unless

R400.12327 Special evaluation.
(5) Within 15 days of the conclusion of the evaluation, an

In six of seven special evaluations reviewed the name of the

Additionally; two of the seven special evaluations, did not show
consistent documentation of the place of the contact.
Repeat Violation, Renewal 2017.

Policy FOM 722- Family Team Meeting
6 B
FTMs should include child welfare staff, parents, caretakers,
foster parents, children, youth, and may also include extended
family, friends, neighbors, community-based service providers,
community representatives, tribal representatives, for Indian
children, or other professionals involved with the family.
Placement Preservation/ Disruption
At least three business days prior to a planned change of
placement or no later than three business days after an
unplanned placement change.
Planned and unplanned placement changes include
reunification, placement in a residential setting, step-down from
a residential or hospital setting, return from AWOLP, or request

Policy FOM 722- Foster Care Action Summary.
09 C
The Foster Care/Juvenile Justice (FC/JJ) Action Summary,
DHS-69 (RFF 69), is used whenever there is “action” on a case.

The DHS worker must complete the DHS-69, Action Summary

requirements for replacement documentation (See FOM 722-
03) and in most cases, agency transfer and case closing
summary (see below). The FC/JJ action summary must also be
used for foster care transfer to adoption.
Which Cases/ When What does this mean

 A replacement.
 Case closing.

Policy FOM 722- Maintaining Connections Through Visitation and Contact:
06I Supplementing Parenting time.
Supplementing Parenting Time
Parents should continually be involved in activities and planning
for their child, unless documented as harmful to the child. These
activities may be used as a way to supplement additional visits,
above the minimum number of required visits. Examples of
acceptable activities include, but are not limited to the following:
 Involvement in medical and dental appointments.
 Attendance at school conferences, sporting events, plays,
recitals, etc.

CI 16-182a Communication Issuance.
Security Awareness Training for Fingerprint Base Criminal
History Requirements
Security Awareness Training (SAT) is required for authorized
personnel who have been granted access to fingerprint-based
Criminal History Record Information (CHRI). This training
provides information on what fingerprint based CHRI is, who
has access, how to ensure this information remains secure both
physically an electronically, and how you can use this
information appropriately.
Security Awareness Training is required to be completed no
later than Tuesday February 10, 2017 for all non-contracted and
governmental CPA employees, subcontractors, subcontractor’s
employees or volunteers who are authorized to have access to
fingerprint-based CHRI.
All non-contracted and governmental CPA employees,
subcontractors, subcontractor’s employees or volunteers who
are authorized to have access to fingerprint-based CHRI must
successfully complete SAT within six months of appointment to
a position with CHRI access and every two years thereafter.

did not show documentation the employee completed the
required training by the 2/10/17 due date.

VI. EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
There was one incident of substantiated corporal punishment during this
licensing period.
This incident related to an allegation pertaining to the foster mother getting into an
argument with her adoptive son, whom she had not reported was back in the home.
It was alleged the incident involved the foster parent’s adult son, pulling a knife on
the foster parent’s adoptive son’s, police involvement and the foster parent putting
the adoptive son out of the home. During the investigation it was revealed the foster
mother was physically disciplining one of the foster children. The foster parent
denied the physical discipline, yet the child, the adoptive son, and another foster
child all reported the foster parent hits the child. During the investigation the foster
parent also refused to accept return of her adoptive son after he was released from
a psychiatric hospital. A maltreatment in care petition was filed against the foster
parent by children services. The agency found the foster home in violation of the
foster home behavior management and foster home reporting of foster home
changes rules. The foster parent was placed on central registry and revocation of
the foster parent’s foster home license was recommended.
The agency adhered to all departmental requirements except R400.1237 (5) (d) and
(e) as indicated earlier in this report.
There was one incident of behavior management during the licensing period.

rule. A corrective action plan was completed.

filling in, and continued team work.

Safety Alert and Concern Alert #11
Concern:
Prior to arrival the relative care provider reported that the child does not reside with her.
An email was sent to the agency confirming this information. A follow email was not
23

received; however, a follow phone call was received from the relative scheduling a visit.
Upon arrival the relative stated the child has not been placed in her care since July
2018 after a court hearing. The child was placed with the fictive-kin biological paternal
grandmother around the corner. The baby was not home at the time, and this analyst
was told that the baby left with biological mother. It should be noted that the biological
mother, (a permanent custody petition has been ordered to be filed on the mother), and
the relative care-giver live side by side in a duplex. There was not a crib or anything for
the baby in the relative-care provider's home, and the relative provider reports that the
baby has not lived there since July. The relative caregiver stated that the baby was
placed with the fictive kin by court order in July. The bio mother brought the child back
to home, and stated the child was residing in her care. The child appeared ok during the
visit. The bio mother contacted Wayne County DHHS worker, Ms. Seabrook. The
analyst spoke with Ms. Seabrook and asked her to provide clarification regarding
placement. Ms. Seabrooks stated the child is placed with the relative. Ms. Seabrooks
stated she was on her way to the home with the current court order.
It is unclear why the child was allowed to be alone with the biological mother who had
her rights terminated on four other children in North Carolina. Please note during the
visit family members were arguing and swearing with each other. The relative care-
giver did not really seem to want the baby but did not want the baby in foster care.
The agency is asked to do the following immediately,
1. Make sure that there is a crib for the baby with the relative care giver.
2. Determine and report on the alert where the baby is living.
3.Provide an explanation for why the worker who by policy is to visit the relative care-
giver for announced and unannounced visits was not aware that there was not a crib or
other belonging at the relative- care giver's home, thus making it a strong possibility that
the baby is not residing there.
4. Find out how much time that the baby spends with the fictive kin since the relative
care giver seemed to think that the baby resides with the fictive kin. Please provide
information regarding this in the alert.
5. Address with the family the fact that no one should allow the baby to go with the
biological mother. She has supervised visits and she has a permanent custody petition
pending.
6. The bottom line is who is providing care for this baby?
Resolution:
The agency reported it made a prompt home visit when it was notified of the Safety

day. The child was placed with a relative, after a DHS 588 and background checks
